results.title: Rose Hill: life on a string
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: Rose is a 90-year-old woman whose passion in life is puppetry, her studio in Mildura is filled with thousands of puppets, showcasing her family’s life long work. Rose introduced puppets to her four sons as a way to enhance their learning; this started a fascination for her son Ross, who became a world renowned puppeteer, working with Jim Henson on the film ‘Labyrinth’. Rose is an inspirational and vibrant woman who is still active in her community.

results.title: Young Philly
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: Phillip is a 20-year-old Hip Hop artist from Mildura who won the prestigious Noel Tovey Achievement Award in 2010 (for Emerging Artist). Despite having a difficult start in life, Phil is intent on living a positive life and breaking the negative stereotypes associated with young Aboriginal people. He shares his passion for rapping with a desire to become a youth worker in the hopes of one day establishing a youth centre for Indigenous kids in Mildura.

results.title: Settlement Soccer Club
results.brief_description: Gene started a Friday afternoon soccer game at the Inverloch Community Hub, in south-eastern Victoria, and invited some young people from the Settlement communities to share in their love of the world game. ‘The Settlement Soccer Club’ is about connecting with others in the community and breaking down boundaries with the international language of the beautiful game. Anyone is welcome to play.

Anyone is welcome to play.

group.title: ACMI in the regions: Stories from Bass Coast

group_siblings.title: Life in the waves: a story about Island Surfboards

results.title: Swell Mamas
results.brief_description: Lucy and Geraldine have been the best of friends since school, when they both became mums they decided that their love of surfing and of being in the water would not take a back seat, so they started ‘Swell Mamas’. Dozens of mums across Inverloch in south-eastern Victoria, get together every Friday morning to connect, to laugh, to share and to feel the water wash over them.

results.title: The Ripple and the shed
results.brief_description: Inverloch’s Clock Tower Committee and Historical Society, in south-eastern Victoria, joined forces to create a maritime precinct along the town’s foreshore. The lovingly restored ‘Rocket Shed’ and newly built replica of ‘The Ripple’ sit side-by-side and showcase Inverloch’s connection to the water. ‘The Ripple’ is responsible for delivering timber for the first house built in Inverloch and the ‘Rocket Shed’ tells the story of a time when ocean rescues were less sophisticated than recent times.

results.title: The Bass Valley Community Centre
results.brief_description: When Clare Le Serve started a craft group for young mums in the early 1980s, she could not have imagined that it would grow over the next 30 years to become such an amazing community asset. With the help of local volunteers and paid staff, the Community Centre offers essential services that make a positive impact on the people of Bass and the surrounding Waterline region in south-eastern Victoria.

results.title: The Corinella Jetty
results.brief_description: In 2005, the small waterline community of Corinella in south eastern Victoria, was at risk of losing its iconic jetty. Barbara Oates, a local and owner of the general store, rallied the community to raise $10,000 to have the jetty renovated and extended, ensuring the prominent landmark would be enjoyed for generations to come.

results.title: Following their footsteps
results.brief_description: The small towns of Kernot and Grantville in south-eastern Victoria, depend on volunteer emergency services to ensure that when fires break out, car accidents happen or cats are stuck in trees, that someone is there to help. Who better to have on call than local legend Barrie Stewart and the dedicated members of the Kernot/Grantville CFA.

results.title: Community banking Bass Coast
results.brief_description: Early in 2001, the banks pulled out of the small coastal town of San Remo in south eastern Victoria, leaving the community with a challenge. Rather than sit on his hands and accept the inevitable consequences of downsizing, a local hardware store owner, Terry Ashenden, pulled together a committee of residents and business owners to overcome the problem.

results.title: DAK: David Alexander Kopelman
results.brief_description: yDAK doesn’t consider himself an artist, he just “dabbles and makes stuff”. Despite this his scrap-metal sculptures and decorative gates can be found throughout the neighbourhoods, businesses and galleries of the Bass Coast in south-eastern Victoria. Cape Woolamai’s very own mo-hawked road warrior has a plasma cutter and he’s not afraid to use it!
